Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Molecular Mechanics Dictate the Mechanical Behavior of an Extracellular Matrix Fiber

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of the research is to characterize the mechanical properties of the fibrillar form of fibronectin, and extracellular matrix structure that is essential for development and that is upregulated in pathologies such as cancer and atherosclerosis, through the analysis of a model system of fibronectin fibers and the use of a computational model built upon the stochastic properties of fibronectin molecules. Fibronectin is assembled into a unique material in vivo with extreme extensibility, leading to speculation that its litany of binding sites for cells and cell signaling molecules may be actuated by mechanical force. This proposal is unique in that it will quantify physical properties of fibronectin fibers that define its function in vivo over a wide range of mechanical strains and attempt to connect these physical properties with the molecular architecture of the fiber. The approach will utilize a technique for quantifying the molecular structure of fibronectin molecules in model fibers that will be compared with a computational model of fibronectin fiber mechanical properties that considers both molecular unfolding and entropic spring-like behavior of fibronectin molecules.

By combining all of these efforts, we expect this interdisciplinary proposal not only to generate a fundamental understanding of the underlying mechanisms governing mechanotransduction but also to have broad ranging implications in regenerative medicine and tissue engineering due to the fundamental role of fibronectin in vivo. It is surprising that despite our vast understanding of the importance of the physical environment on the behavior of virtually every studied cell, relatively little is known about the properties of native extracellular matrix structures. This program will be transformative in its capacity to promote new approaches in mechanotransduction research, as well as to immerse undergraduate and graduate students in a broad range of technological innovation. Active participation of both women and minority students will be fostered via a collaborative relationship with the Society of Women Engineers and Minority Engineers Society. Furthermore, this project will serve as a vehicle for the development of lab modules for courses at Boston University and Cornell University that are targeted for 3rd year undergraduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
PROJECT SUMMARY: The extracellular matrix (ECM) is a multi-protein network used by cells to communicate with their environment. This research aimed at characterizing the structure and mechanics of fibronectin, a protein found in the ECM that is essential for development and that is found in high quantities in pathologies such as cancer and atherosclerosis. In vivo, cells assemble fibronectin into a unique network of highly stretched fibers, leading to speculation that the numerous binding sites of fibronectin for cells and cell signaling molecules may be exposed/activated only under mechanical pulling forces (exerted by the surrounding cells).

INTELLECTUAL MERIT: This proposal was unique in that it quantified the mechanical properties (rigidity and viscosity) of fibronectin fibers that define their function in vivo over a wide range of mechanical deformations, and connected these properties with the molecular structure (architecture) of the fibers. Our approach utilized an optical technique called FRET for quantifying the structure of fibronectin molecules in both cell-made and man-made model fibers that was later compared with a computational model of fibronectin molecules.

BROADER IMPACTS: Overall, this three-year interdisciplinary proposal has (i) generated a fundamental understanding of the mechanisms governing cells interactions with their environment (here ECM fibronectin fibers) and (ii) clarified the role of mechanical stretching on the deregulation of such interactions in breast cancer environments. In such a context, it is expected to have broad ranging implications in (bio)materials science, tissue engineering, and regenerative medicine in the near future due to the fundamental role of fibronectin in vivo. Educationally, this program has introduced students (K-12, undergraduate, and graduate) and teachers (GK-12 program) to the fields of (and the tools used in) materials and biomaterials science, biomechanics, protein physics, and cell biology. The PI has also trained undergraduate and graduate students for future jobs in (bio)materials science and/or engineering through (i) mentoring students from freshman to graduate level in research and (ii) integrating research into her three undergraduate and graduate level interdisciplinary courses taught across seven departments at Cornell. Finally, active participation of both women and minority students has been fostered via a collaborative relationship with the Women in Materials Science and Engineering (WIMSE) Society and the Minority Engineers Society.
